title: Investment Banker Roadmap
description: Welcome to the high-stakes world of corporate finance. An Investment Banker is a financial advisor to corporations, governments, and other institutions. You're a deal-maker, helping companies raise money, merge with or acquire other companies, and navigate complex financial situations. It's a world of high pressure, long hours, and immense rewards. This is your quest to master the art of the deal.

steps.name: Master Financial Accounting
steps.details: Accounting is the language of business, and you need to be fluent in it. This is the absolute, non-negotiable foundation of everything you will do. You must be able to read and interpret the three core financial statements – the Income Statement, Balance Sheet, and Cash Flow Statement – and understand how they connect. An investment banker who doesn't understand accounting is like a surgeon who doesn't understand anatomy.

resources.title: Wall Street Prep or Breaking Into Wall Street Accounting Courses
Financial Statement Analysis by Martin Fridson

key_learnings: The Three Financial Statements and how they link

steps.name: Develop Advanced Excel Skills
steps.details: Excel is your primary tool, your workshop, and your canvas. You will live and breathe in Excel. You need to be a wizard at it, capable of building complex financial models quickly and accurately without ever touching the mouse. Speed and precision are paramount. Every second you save by using a keyboard shortcut is a second you get back in your day.

resources.title: Wall Street Prep or Breaking Into Wall Street Excel Courses
Rebuild financial models you find online from scratch

key_learnings: Keyboard Shortcuts (Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V are just the beginning)
Advanced Formulas: INDEX, MATCH, OFFSET, CHOOSE

steps.name: Understand Corporate Finance Theory
steps.details: This is the 'why' behind the numbers. You need to understand the core theories of corporate finance. What is the time value of money? How do you calculate the cost of capital? What is the relationship between risk and return? These concepts form the intellectual backbone of financial valuation and strategic decision-making.
key_learnings: Net Present Value (NPV) and Internal Rate of Return (IRR)

stages.title: Phase 2: The Art of Valuation (The Core Skillset)

steps.name: Master Financial Modeling
steps.details: A financial model is a forecast of a company's future financial performance. Building a three-statement financial model is a core skill. You'll take historical data, make assumptions about the future, and project the company's income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement out for several years. This model is the foundation for all other valuation work.

resources.title: Wall Street Prep or Breaking Into Wall Street Financial Modeling Courses

steps.name: Learn Comparable Company Analysis (Comps)
steps.details: This is a relative valuation method where you value a company by looking at what similar companies are worth. It's like pricing a house by looking at the sale prices of similar houses in the neighborhood. You'll learn how to select a peer group of companies, gather their financial data, and calculate key trading multiples like EV/EBITDA and P/E.

resources.title: Macabacus or Street of Walls guides on Comps

key_learnings: Calculating Enterprise Value and Equity Value
Understanding the pros and cons of this method

steps.name: Learn Precedent Transaction Analysis (Transactions)
steps.details: Similar to Comps, this method values a company by looking at what similar companies have been acquired for in the past. This gives you an idea of what a company might be worth in an acquisition scenario, which is often higher than its standalone trading value due to a 'control premium.'

resources.title: Macabacus or Street of Walls guides on Precedent Transactions

steps.name: Master Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis
steps.details: The DCF is the foundation of intrinsic valuation. The idea is simple: a company's value is the sum of all the cash it will generate in the future, discounted back to today's value. In practice, it's a complex model that combines your 3-statement forecast with corporate finance theory (like WACC). A well-built DCF is considered the most intellectually rigorous valuation method.

resources.title: Wall Street Prep or Breaking Into Wall Street DCF Modeling Courses

key_learnings: Calculating Terminal Value (Gordon Growth and Exit Multiple methods)

steps.name: Learn M&A and LBO Modeling
steps.details: Now you start modeling the deals themselves. An M&A (Mergers & Acquisitions) model analyzes the financial impact of one company acquiring another. A Leveraged Buyout (LBO) model analyzes a transaction where a company is acquired using a significant amount of debt. LBO modeling is the specialty of private equity, but bankers need to master it as well. These are the most complex models you will build.

resources.title: Wall Street Prep or Breaking Into Wall Street M&A and LBO Courses

key_learnings: M&A: Accretion/Dilution analysis, sources and uses, purchase price allocation
LBO: Modeling debt tranches, calculating investor returns (IRR)

steps.name: Develop Strong Communication and Presentation Skills
steps.details: All of your brilliant financial models are useless if you can't communicate their conclusions. You will spend a huge amount of time creating presentations (pitch books) in PowerPoint. You need to be able to distill complex analyses into clear, persuasive slides. You also need to be a confident and articulate presenter, capable of defending your work to managing directors and clients.

resources.title: Learn PowerPoint inside and out. Practice presenting your models.

key_learnings: Creating compelling pitch books and CIMs (Confidential Information Memorandums)
Attention to detail (typos can kill credibility)

steps.name: Understand the Deal Process and Network
steps.details: Investment banking is a client-facing business built on relationships. You need to understand the lifecycle of a deal, from the initial pitch to the final closing. You also need to be an effective networker. This means building relationships with colleagues, clients, and other professionals in the industry. The technical skills get you in the door, but the soft skills are what make you successful long-term.

resources.title: Conduct informational interviews with bankers. Follow financial news religiously.

key_learnings: The M&A and capital raising deal lifecycles
Market awareness (staying on top of deals and trends)
Developing a strong work ethic and resilience
